title: The Choice to Love
sub_title: Lessons from a Lifetime of Love
devotional:
Old Mr. Abernathy sat on his porch swing, watching the leaves fall. October painted the world in hues of gold and crimson, a beautiful farewell before winter's stark embrace. He remembered a time when this view filled him with joy, when his late wife, Clara, would sit beside him, a steaming mug of apple cider in her hands, and they'd simply *be* together. Now, the silence was a heavy blanket, woven with memories and longing.

Across the street, a young couple, barely more than children in his eyes, were arguing. Their voices, sharp and laced with frustration, carried on the crisp autumn air. Mr. Abernathy sighed. He recognized the dance – the misunderstandings, the unspoken needs, the fear of vulnerability. He’d danced it himself, decades ago. He remembered the sting of harsh words, the cold silence that followed, the slow, painstaking work of rebuilding. He and Clara hadn't always been perfect; they'd had their share of storms. But their love, like a sturdy oak, had weathered them all.

Suddenly, the young woman stormed off, leaving her partner standing alone, shoulders slumped with defeat. Mr. Abernathy felt a pang of empathy. He knew that loneliness, that feeling of being utterly disconnected from the one you were supposed to be closest to.

Love, he realized, wasn't just a feeling; it was a choice. A daily, conscious decision to put the other person's needs before your own, to forgive freely, to listen with an open heart, and to offer grace, even when it wasn't deserved. It was about seeing the beauty in imperfections, the potential for growth, and the shared humanity that bound two souls together.

He rose slowly, creaking joints protesting with each movement. He poured himself a glass of lemonade (Clara always made sure he had some, even in October) and walked across the street. He didn't know if his words would make a difference, but he couldn't stand by and watch another love story unravel without at least trying to offer a little bit of wisdom, gleaned from a lifetime of loving and losing.

"Sometimes," he said, his voice raspy but kind, "the strongest love is the one that perseveres through the hard times. Don't give up too easily."
image_description: A wooden porch swing with fallen autumn leaves scattered around, a glass of lemonade sitting on a small table next to the swing.
insights: 1 Corinthians 13:4-7 provides a timeless description of love: 'Love is patient, love is kind. It does not envy, it does not boast, it is not proud. It does not dishonor others, it is not self-seeking, it is not easily angered, it keeps no record of wrongs. Love does not delight in evil but rejoices with the truth. It always protects, always trusts, always hopes, always perseveres.' This passage emphasizes the active and intentional nature of love, highlighting qualities such as patience, kindness, and forgiveness.
prayer: Heavenly Father, teach me what it means to truly love. Help me to be patient and kind, to forgive freely, and to put the needs of others before my own. Grant me the strength to persevere through difficult times and to always choose love, even when it's hard. Remind me that Your love is the foundation of all relationships and that with You, all things are possible. In Jesus' name, Amen.
reflection: In what areas of your life are you struggling to show love? How can you apply the principles of 1 Corinthians 13 to your relationships? What small step can you take today to demonstrate love to someone who needs it?
